channel.title: Linux Outlaws
channel.description: Two pragmatic geeks talk about the latest news concerning Linux, free and open technology or anything else they deem noteworthy which may include such absurd things as hockey or bands you never heard of. This means there's many a joke and derailed conversation along the way, so don't come here expecting only Linux or software freedom talk — just sit back and relax, partner.
channel.itunes:subtitle: The hardest-hitting Linux podcast around
channel.itunes:summary: Two pragmatic geeks talk about the latest news concerning Linux, free and open technology or anything else they deem noteworthy which may include such absurd things as hockey or bands you never heard of. This means there's many a joke and derailed conversation along the way, so don't come here expecting only Linux or software freedom talk — just sit back and relax, partner.
channel.itunes:author: Sixgun Productions

item.title: Linux Outlaws 284 – Burning Poppies
item.dc:creator: linuxoutlaws@sixgun.org (Sixgun Productions)
item.description: John McAfee wanted for murder, Mozilla Festival 2012 report, Fedora 19 release name voting, AMD lays of many of its open source developers, Oracle tries to piss off Red Hat, Brocade buys Vyatta, Linus on the Android kernel and a comeback of the Gaming Corner
item.content:encoded:
Uncut video version of this episode on YouTube

0:00:47 INTRODUCTION

  • Breaking News: McAfee wanted for murder in Belize
  • Northeast Linux Fest is looking for speakers
  • Dan’s Beer of the Week: Grafenwalder Pils
  • Someone needs to sort out our Wikipedia entry
  • Kent police arrests man for burning a fake poppy — #poppycock
  • There will be no live show on Monday, we will be recording later in the week

0:22:34 REPORT FROM MOZFEST

 Fab attended the Mozilla Festival 2012 in London and gives his report.

  • Popcorn Maker 1.0
  • Webmaker Badges

The Mozfest Blimp

0:36:15 RELEASES & NEWS

  • openSUSE 12.2 for ARM
  • Development: Mandriva 2012 Alpha 2
  • Development: Linux Mint 14 RC1
  • Development: First E17 alpha
  • Development: Ruby 2.0.0 preview
  • TOR security issue
  • Apple and HTC settle all patent lawsuits
  • Fedora 19 release name voting
  • AMD lays off open source developers
  • Oracle tries to piss off Red Hat with RedPatch
  • Plone vulnerabilities
  • Brocade acquires Vyetta
  • Matthew Garrett has quit his job for Red Hat
  • Ubuntu for Android marketing video
  • Go turns three
  • AlaMode backpacks an Arduino on a Raspberry Pi
  • Mozilla settles with the IRS
  • Linus Torvalds: The Android situation is improving
  • GNOME drops fallback mode

1:23:35 GAMING CORNER

  • Steam for Linux is a go and Fab has cheated his way in; a full report will be forthcoming
  • Elite: Dangerous — Fab is a backer

Concept art for Elite: Dangerous

1:30:35 FEEDBACK

Supporters: We thank Remy van Elst and all Flattr’ers!

  • Neil had a long email discussion with Fab about Republicanism
  • Chris wanted to point us to a ranty article about the state of GNOME 3
  • Kristin Morey enjoys the show and looks forward to it each week; she also tells us about working with her Chromebook CR-48 running Debian with KDE
  • Kuero says Fab should use one of his Raspberry Pis as a Bitcoin miner

Song: A Drone Again, Naturally by Drone Aircraft (all rights reserved)
item.itunes:subtitle: John McAfee wanted for murder, Mozilla Festival 2012 report, Fedora 19 release name voting, AMD lays of many of its open source developers, Oracle tries to piss off Red Hat, Brocade buys Vyatta, Linus on the Android kernel and a comeback of the Gami[...]
item.itunes:summary: John McAfee wanted for murder, Mozilla Festival 2012 report, Fedora 19 release name voting, AMD lays of many of its open source developers, Oracle tries to piss off Red Hat, Brocade buys Vyatta, Linus on the Android kernel and a comeback of the Gaming Corner
item.itunes:author: fab@sixgun.org

item.title: Linux Outlaws 283 – Remember, Remember
item.dc:creator: linuxoutlaws@sixgun.org (Sixgun Productions)
item.description: Fab reviews the Kindle Paperwhite, Anonymous action on the Fifth of November, German Zollfahndung looking for malware coders, Ubuntu drops alphas and all but one beta, Android turns 5, Richard Stallman seeks to limit the scope of software patents and rooting doesn't void your warranty in the EU
item.content:encoded:
Uncut video version of this episode on YouTube

0:01:00 INTRODUCTION

  • Bruce and Jay-Z rally for Obama

Barack Obama hugs Bruce Springsteen on the day before the election

  • Fab now has two Raspberry Pis he wants to use for Sixgun-related projects, thanks to Mike!
  • Fab interviewed Carsten “Rasterman” Haitzler on E17
  • Dan recommends Iron Sky

0:17:59 RELEASES & NEWS

  • Tiny Core 4.7
  • DragonFly BSD 3.2.1
  • OpenBSD 5.2
  • libvirt 1.0.0
  • Asterisk 11.0
  • Ubuntu Tweak 0.8.2
  • Bootstrap 2.2
  • Sigil 0.6.0
  • Anonymous at work on 5 November?
  • High-speed bank fraud at casinos
  • Vupen brags about Windows 8 exploit
  • German Zollfahndung looking for malware coders
  • Telefónica wants to turn customer data into cash
  • LinuxCon Europe starts with new and upgraded members
  • More info on the ext4 bug, it’s patched now
  • Matthew Garrett details the current state of Secure Boot
  • Ubuntu: No more alphas, just one beta
  • Wikimedia launches Wikidata and reports on Wikipedia Zero
  • Android turns 5
  • Markdown may become a standard
  • Richard Stallman seeks to limit the scope of software patents
  • Rooting does not void warranties in the EU

1:15:21 IN-DEPTH

Fab reviews the wifi-only model of the Kindle Paperwhite.

The Kindle Paperwhite in a dark room

1:31:23 FEEDBACK

Supporters: Kristin Morey, Daniel Lowe and all Flattr’ers

  • We had some comments from Stuart Langridge and Jono Bacon about Ubuntu on the Nexus 7; Jono also wrote a blog post on the topic
  • Fab had lots of discussions with people over eeminism after last week’s show
  • Tailzer sent on something from the NHS Open Source Skunkworks team; they apparently think iOS is open source
  • Ron McCy enjoyed Fab’s interview with Carsten “Rasterman” Haitzler about E17
  • Jordan Mears enjoys the show and tells us about his personal open source project called Cider, which is a web-based IDE; he  just released version 0.7 and could use some user feedback
  • Jason Bowles says his wife does not like Android’s auto-completion

We also had email from Ivan Pejić.

Song: Ain’t That Good News from the album Drop By Drop by Daniel Berges & The Windsurfers (licensed Creative Commons BY-NC-SA 3.0)
item.itunes:subtitle: Fab reviews the Kindle Paperwhite, Anonymous action on the Fifth of November, German Zollfahndung looking for malware coders, Ubuntu drops alphas and all but one beta, Android turns 5, Richard Stallman seeks to limit the scope of software patents an[...]
item.itunes:summary: Fab reviews the Kindle Paperwhite, Anonymous action on the Fifth of November, German Zollfahndung looking for malware coders, Ubuntu drops alphas and all but one beta, Android turns 5, Richard Stallman seeks to limit the scope of software patents and rooting doesn't void your warranty in the EU
item.itunes:author: fab@sixgun.org

item.title: Linux Outlaws 282 – Lazy Unmount
item.dc:creator: linuxoutlaws@sixgun.org (Sixgun Productions)
item.description: Skyfall, Ubuntu privacy problems, Ubuntu GNOME Remix, Google unveils Android 4.2 and three Nexus devices, the ext4 furor, Ada Initiative attacks Ted Ts'o because over comments, Ubuntu installer for the Nexus 7 and more
item.content:encoded:
Uncut video version of this episode on YouTube

0:01:10 INTRODUCTION

  • Our thoughts go out to those in Sandy country

Obviously, the Russians don’t give a fuck

  • Fab says Skyfall is awesome
  • Speaking of Bond: Rachel Ter Horst was in GoldenEye
  • Fab recommends you listen to Rum Doings, it’s amazingly funny!
  • The Independent Characters are nominated for the Podcast Awards in the Gaming category, vote for them!
  • Dan wrote a quick guide to pimping SMS on your Android phone

0:11:50 RELEASES & NEWS

  • FreeNAS 8.3
  • Ubuntu 12.10 GNOME Remix
  • Cairo-Dock 3.1
  • Wayland 1.0
  • Git 1.8.0
  • Mono 3.0
  • systemd 195
  • Airtime 2.2
  • Development: Firefox introduces Social API
  • Kindle Paperwhite review coming up from Fab
  • Exim mail server vulnerability
  • Google unveils Android 4.2 and three Nexus devices
  • Raspberry Pi graphics drivers open sourced
  • An ext4 bug and its consequences
  • Carbonite buys Zmanda
  • W3C Push API draft
  • Dell donates ARM concept server to the ASF
  • Ada Initiative goes off on Ted Ts’o for a two year old rape comment
  • The 25 worst passwords of the year
  • Ubuntu installer for the Nexus 7
  • Steam for Linux beta — actually, it’s just Steam for Ubuntu
  • The EFF warns of privacy problems with the Dash search in Ubuntu 12.10

1:20:56 FEEDBACK

Supporters: Gary Sellani, Kirk Richard Holz, Armin Krauss, Dorian Okrucinski, Evgeny Kuznetsov and everyone who Flattr’ed us.

  • B1ackCr0w praises Macmillan Cancer Support
  • Remy van Elst requests a song by The Beards that we already played back in the day and also pimps his software project, a server monitor
  • Alex Benee reflects on Ubuntu’s release and features policy
  • Jesse wants us to explain what systemd is about

We had other emails from Kerry and NYBill.

  • Joss Whedon on Mitt Romney

Song: Mustapha by Urban Castle Magic from the album Let it GO! (licensed Creative Commons BY-NC-SA 3.0)
item.itunes:subtitle: Skyfall, Ubuntu privacy problems, Ubuntu GNOME Remix, Google unveils Android 4.2 and three Nexus devices, the ext4 furor, Ada Initiative attacks Ted Ts'o because over comments, Ubuntu installer for the Nexus 7 and more
item.itunes:summary: Skyfall, Ubuntu privacy problems, Ubuntu GNOME Remix, Google unveils Android 4.2 and three Nexus devices, the ext4 furor, Ada Initiative attacks Ted Ts'o because over comments, Ubuntu installer for the Nexus 7 and more
item.itunes:author: fab@sixgun.org

item.title: Linux Outlaws 281 – Cheri, Cheri Lady
item.dc:creator: linuxoutlaws@sixgun.org (Sixgun Productions)
item.description: We catch up on a whole lot of news, including Google's earning fiasco, the Cover Art Archive, Fedora retiring Smolt, OSI and OSHWA settling their logo dispute, NVIDIA controversy about GPL symbols and much more...
item.content:encoded:
Uncut video version of this episode on YouTube

0:01:00 INTRODUCTION

  • Following on from our Ubuntu 12.10 review show, we have quite a lot of news

0:03:47 RELEASES & NEWS

  • NetBSD 6.0
  • Firefox 16: released, pulled, re-released
  • Development: Firefox Marketplace
  • Rust 0.4
  • Piwik 1.9
  • VLC 2.0.4
  • Juju web interface — open source, from Canonical
  • Ubuntu Tweak 0.8 — although it is now dead
  • Development: Mesa 9.0
  • miniFlame
  • Pinkie Pie does it again at Pwnium 2
  • US patent on DRM system for 3D printers
  • Google fucks up announcing their (bad) quarterly results, causing shares to take a nosedive
  • Cover Art Archive announced
  • Mandriva Foundation gets a name
  • Fedora retires Smolt
  • OSI and OSHWA settle dispute over logo
  • OpenOffice now a top level project of the ASF
  • Raspberry Pi now with double memory
  • Google announces ARM Chromebooks
  • Linux Foundation presents Secure Boot solution; also see FaiF 0×32
  • NVIDIA wants to remove GPL markers from the Linux interface
  • Fedora is delayed and delayed again

1:01:37 MICROWATCH

  • Microsoft’s profits fall 22%
  • Nokia’s numbers are shit too

1:07:43 FEEDBACK

 Supporters: Thanks to Rob Hall, David Guest, Yosi Shibberu, Matt Kraai and all the flattr’ers for stepping up!

  • Alan Bailward tells us we got the facts on Tim Cook’s apology for the Apple Maps fiasco wrong
  • Paula Graham sends a message via Les Pounder about the FLOSS Talent Women’s Career Taster from Flossie
  • Gary tells us about the meetBSD conference in California on 3 & 4 November

The horror…. the horror!!

  • Uwe Schuerkamp writes from imaginary Bielefeld about Blue Systems
  • Sergei Van Hardeveld wrote to us about the Humble eBook Bundle (which is now over)

We also had an email from Keith Z-G.

Song: Nanowar from the album Into Gay Pride Ride by Nanowar (licensed under a Creative Commons licence)
item.itunes:subtitle: We catch up on a whole lot of news, including Google's earning fiasco, the Cover Art Archive, Fedora retiring Smolt, OSI and OSHWA settling their logo dispute, NVIDIA controversy about GPL symbols and much more...
item.itunes:summary: We catch up on a whole lot of news, including Google's earning fiasco, the Cover Art Archive, Fedora retiring Smolt, OSI and OSHWA settling their logo dispute, NVIDIA controversy about GPL symbols and much more...
item.itunes:author: fab@sixgun.org

item.title: Linux Outlaws 280 – Rusty Ringpiece
item.dc:creator: linuxoutlaws@sixgun.org (Sixgun Productions)
item.description: We bring you the latest Ubuntu news, including Fab's review of the recently released Ubuntu 12.10 "Quantal Quetzal". WARNING: Contains rants!
item.content:encoded:
Uncut video version of this episode on YouTube

UBUNTU NEWS SPECIAL

In this show, we bring you the latest Ubuntu news and Fab gives his review of Ubuntu 12.10 “Quantal Quetzal”. We also discuss Mark Shuttleworth’ latest blogging spree.

  • Fab’s in-depth review of Ubuntu 12.10 on The H

Miss Ter Horst would like to help you with that command line business

  • Ubuntu donation page
  • Ubuntu 13.04 named after a raccoon

Fab has a bit of a rant…

  • Shuttleworth blogs
  • …and then backpaddles
  • Commentary on the blog post before he rephrased parts of it

Song: Code Monkey (Slashdot 15th Birthday Edition) by Jonathan Coulton (all rights reserved)
item.itunes:subtitle: We bring you the latest Ubuntu news, including Fab's review of the recently released Ubuntu 12.10 "Quantal Quetzal". WARNING: Contains rants!
item.itunes:summary: We bring you the latest Ubuntu news, including Fab's review of the recently released Ubuntu 12.10 "Quantal Quetzal". WARNING: Contains rants!
item.itunes:author: fab@sixgun.org

item.title: Linux Outlaws 279 – Double Oh Seventy
item.dc:creator: linuxoutlaws@sixgun.org (Sixgun Productions)
item.description: Mass extinction in World of Warcraft, epic trollage of a security magazine, Red Hat crop circles, Oracle appeals Java case against Google, Blue Systems hires another KDE developer and Jolla patents the shit out of MeeGo
item.content:encoded:
Uncut video version of this episode on YouTube

0:01:29 INTRODUCTION

  • Apparently we are nominated for the European Podcast Awards
  • Hands on with Harald Welte’s open GSM base station
  • Fab logs beers on Untappd

0:13:25 RELEASES & NEWS

  • Debian 6.0.6
  • Arch Linux 2012.10.06
  • First release candidate for openSUSE on ARM
  • Blender 2.64
  • MythTV 0.26
  • FFmpeg 1.0
  • Banshee 2.6
  • Firefox “Metro” preview
  • NIST names Keccak as SHA-3
  • Android malware can create 3D maps of rooms
  • NMAP dev trolls pesky security magazine
  • Mass extinction hack hits World of Warcraft
  • Red Hat crop circles

What the fuck is an “enterpriser”?

  • Oracle appeals Google/Java case
  • 64-bit ARM support coming to the kernel
  • Wii Balance Board support in the kernel
  • JavaOne 2012: Oracle’s plan for Java in the next year
  • JBoss is looking for a new name for its community edition
  • Jolla wants to bring back MeeGo
  • New OpenBSD release song slags off Linux
  • Samsung contributes F2FS NAND filesystem to Linux
  • KWin maintainer goes to Blue Systems

The Blue Systems HQ on Street View

1:13:00 FEEDBACK

Supporters: Rafael Hart, Kerry O’Brien and everyone who flattr’d us

  • Michael Harker is a Windows user learning about Linux and just discovered our show
  • Sam Ross sends us a picture of a very cool Castle apron

The most epic apron ever

  • Allison Chaiken brings up quantum computing again, it seems she knows quite a bit about it
  • We also had a nice email from Kerry who is a new listener and enjoys the show

Song: Crystals by Professor Kliq from the album Curriculum Vitae (licensed Creative Commons BY-SA 3.0)
item.itunes:subtitle: Mass extinction in World of Warcraft, epic trollage of a security magazine, Red Hat crop circles, Oracle appeals Java case against Google, Blue Systems hires another KDE developer and Jolla patents the shit out of MeeGo
item.itunes:summary: Mass extinction in World of Warcraft, epic trollage of a security magazine, Red Hat crop circles, Oracle appeals Java case against Google, Blue Systems hires another KDE developer and Jolla patents the shit out of MeeGo
item.itunes:author: fab@sixgun.org

item.title: Linux Outlaws 278 – Klingon Style
item.dc:creator: linuxoutlaws@sixgun.org (Sixgun Productions)
item.description: A metric ton of releases, Adobe releases another open font, Ubuntu runs into trouble with Amazon advertising in their menus, Neil Young creates his own media player, a new Blender movie is released, CyanogenMod gets its own update manager and much more
item.content:encoded:
Uncut video version of this episode on YouTube: Part 1 & Part 2

0:01:33 INTRODUCTION

  • Fab got hit by the flu and missed Barcamp Blackpool, we also skipped a show because of this
  • Rest in Peace Michael O’Hare

Michael O’Hare as Commander Jeffrey Sinclair in Babylon 5

  • We completely missed the 5th birthday of the show on 12 September — half a decade of Linux Outlaws!
  • Karen Sandler from FaiF had a baby — congratulations!
  • OggCamp documentary trailer
  • Apparently quantum computing is a thing (German link)
  • The H is looking for a fulltime writer (position based in London)

0:14:27 FEATURE CONTENT: BARCAMP BLACKPOOL

Dan recaps his day Barcamp Blackpool this year. This includes a run-in with a vending machine, strangely enough.

0:24:35 RELEASES & NEWS

  • Linux 3.6
  • Slackware 14
  • Fedora 18 Alpha
  • Mandriva 2012 Alpha
  • Ubuntu 12.10 Beta 2
  • Open webOS 1.0
  • GNOME 3.6
  • Cinnamon 1.6
  • Unity 6.6 — featuring controversy and backpaddling
  • Python 3.3.0 — the moratorium has ended, new features
  • GStreamer 1.0
  • Xen 4.2
  • OpenStack Folsom
  • GeeXboX 3.0
  • Source Code Pro from Adobe
  • Adobe hacked and exploited
  • phpMyAdmin distributed with backdoor
  • Android smartphone USSD problem
  • Researchers unravel Flame trojan
  • WhatsApp threatens API developers with legal action
  • Rescuing the original Prince of Persia source code
  • Neil Young creates his own music player — but apparently it’s BS, according to Xiph
  • Bitcoin Foundation launched
  • New Blender Movie: Tears of Steel
  • Automotive Linux Summit
  • Dice Holdings acquires Slashdot & SourceForge from Geeknet
  • Apparently all that “Samsung will help the CyanogenMod guys” talk was just PR (German link)
  • Intel is planning a Clover Trail variant for Linux
  • OpenStack now governed by a foundation
  • Ubuntu will not switch away from GRUB for UEFI boot
  • CyanogenMod gets its own update manager

1:31:30 MICROWATCH

  • Microsoft and Xamarin collaborate on Azure Mobile Services
  • Notch says fuck the Windows 8 app store; background on the Windows 8 app store requirements

1:37:56 CRAPPLEWATCH

  • The Great iOS 6 mapping disaster

1:42:39 FEEDBACK

 Supporters: Mark McNeill, Kai Siers, Timothy Pope, Evgeny Kuznetsov and everyone who flattred us

  • Alexander Logvinov and JLarky write to us about our discussion of the Pussy Riot case
  • Yannick Mauray from Euterpia Radio tells us about Tusaï, his Linux From Scratch distro inspired by our show
  • Eliad tells us about the history of the Clementine audio player
  • Bernd Schlapsi tells us that gPodder 3.3.0 is out and also mentions the gPodder 2.20.2 bugfix release

We had other emails from: Daniel Hartley and Steve Cook.

  • Klingon Style

Oppan Klingon Style!

Song: Water In The Creek by Josh Woodward from the album The Wake (licensed Creative Commons BY 3.0)
item.itunes:subtitle: A metric ton of releases, Adobe releases another open font, Ubuntu runs into trouble with Amazon advertising in their menus, Neil Young creates his own media player, a new Blender movie is released, CyanogenMod gets its own update manager and much m[...]
item.itunes:summary: A metric ton of releases, Adobe releases another open font, Ubuntu runs into trouble with Amazon advertising in their menus, Neil Young creates his own media player, a new Blender movie is released, CyanogenMod gets its own update manager and much more
item.itunes:author: fab@sixgun.org

item.title: Linux Outlaws 277 – Digital Originals
item.dc:creator: linuxoutlaws@sixgun.org (Sixgun Productions)
item.description: GoDaddy fail, German Federal Commissioner prevented from looking at federal malware, Google threatens Acer, KindleBerry Pi, Red Hat uses the GPL to fight back in a patent lawsuit and we interview Kevin O’Brien about the Ohio Linux Fest
item.content:encoded:
Uncut video version of this episode on YouTube

0:00:57 INTRODUCTION

  • Some current affairs talk: The Royals are suing over a bunch of breasts, the whole muslim world is in flames over a stupid film and it seems like that the case against Assange is getting slimmer by the minute

“Lawyer calls for digital originals of topless photos to be handed over” What exactly is a “digital original”? I can hear @jeffjarvis rant.

— Fabian A. Scherschel (@fabsh) September 17, 2012

 

  • It is the one year anniversary of Occupy Wall Street; The Nightwatchman gave a concert for the protesters

The Nightwatchman & The Boss

0:14:48 RELEASES & NEWS

  • Sabayon 10
  • Parted Magic 2012_09_12
  • Piwik 1.8.4
  • Avidemux 2.6.0
  • Chrome for Android update strengthens sandbox
  • Samba 4 RC1
  • Happy birthday, Jono Bacon!
  • PyCon UK 2012 schedule posted
  • LinuxCon Europe 2012 schedule
  • GoDaddy outage, not due to hackers
  • What’s App clusterfuck: Android app, iOS app, general account security
  • EU gets its own CERT
  • PHP 5.5 should reduce password sloppiness
  • German Federal Commissioner unable to audit Federal Trojan source code
  • VMware now OpenStack Foundation member
  • Italy passed open source requirement law
  • NVIDIA to maintain Linux drivers for GeForce 6 and 7 until 2017
  • Google prevents Acer from distributing phones with Aliyun OS
  • Red Hat uses GPL to strike back in patent lawsuit
  • Raspberry Pi now made in the UK, KindleBerry Pi
  • Opus becomes an Internet Standard

1:11:36 MICROWATCH

  • UPEK fingerprint reader leaks Windows passwords

1:16:18 INTERVIEW

We interview Kevin O’Brien about the Ohio Linux Fest.

Ohio Linux Fest / Columbus, Ohio — 28-30 September 2012

1:38:03 FEEDBACK

Supporters: Matthew Jelliman, Remy van Elst and everyone who flattr’d us

  • Kirk Richard Holz enjoys the show and would like us to get someone on to talk about quantum computing
  • Brian Cesar sends us a very nice thank you note
  • We also got a very long email on the subject of Pussy Riot from Russian listener Alexander Loginov
Song: Shaved Off His Beard by The Beards (all rights reserved)
item.itunes:subtitle: GoDaddy fail, German Federal Commissioner prevented from looking at federal malware, Google threatens Acer, KindleBerry Pi, Red Hat uses the GPL to fight back in a patent lawsuit and we interview Kevin O’Brien about the Ohio Linux Fest
item.itunes:summary: GoDaddy fail, German Federal Commissioner prevented from looking at federal malware, Google threatens Acer, KindleBerry Pi, Red Hat uses the GPL to fight back in a patent lawsuit and we interview Kevin O’Brien about the Ohio Linux Fest
item.itunes:author: fab@sixgun.org

item.title: Linux Outlaws 276 – Bum White
item.dc:creator: linuxoutlaws@sixgun.org (Sixgun Productions)
item.description: Fab is back from holiday, Firefox 15 is out, Java is pwned, Fedora 18 is postponed (again), Diaspora is fail and Linux Mint founder Clem calls Nautilus a catastrophe
item.content:encoded:
Uncut video version of this episode on YouTube

0:02:02 INTRODUCTION

  • Barcamp Blackpool
  • PyCon UK
  • Buy Linux Format 163 for some awesome OggCamp goodness
  • Rap News 15 feat. George Torwell

0:11:51 RELEASES & NEWS

  • Tiny Core 4.6 makes finding fast mirrors easier
  • Linux from Scratch 7.2
  • openSUSE 12.2
  • SUSE Cloud 1.0
  • SystemRescueCd 3.0.0 introduces support for modules
  • Firefox 15; Mozilla previews “command line” in Firefox 16 Beta
  • Open WebOS beta
  • KDE 4.9
  • PostgresSQL 9.2
  • X Server 1.13
  • QEMU 1.2.0 improves live migration
  • WordPress 3.4.2
  • FreedomBox 0.1, SANE 1.0.23, Stellarium 0.11.4, Audacity 2.0.2
  • Knoppix 7.0.4, Turbolinux 12.5, WattOS R6, Haiku 64-bit
  • ROSA Enterprise Linux Server
  • Mageia 3 Alpha 1 brings /usr/ merge
  • The new Java 0Day examined; fixes released; latest Java sandbox is still vulnerable; Oracle knew of Java vulnerabilities says researcher
  • Google acquires VirusTotal
  • Fedora 18 postponed a third time
  • Apache ignores Internet Explorer 10′s do-not-track header
  • Raspberry Pi: MPEG-2 and VC-1 licences available
  • Ubuntu to drop alternate installer
  • Diaspora social network to be a community project; Learning from Diaspora
  • OpenIndiana project leader steps down
  • White House open sources its mobile site and apps
  • Linux Mint founder calls Nautilus 3.6 “a catastrophe”

Bum White – it makes your bum white!

0:59:37 MICROWATCH

  •  Pre-release version of Windows 8 contains Flash hole

1:01:36 FEEDBACK

Supporters: Evgeny Kuznetsov, Eric Crampton, Mike Bickerton and everyone who flattr’d us — thanks to all of you!

  • Michael Hanke asks us to mention the death of John Hunter, the author of Python’s matplotlib — there is a fundraising effort to help his family ensure education and support for his three daughters
  • Evgeny Kuznetsov was listening to Episode 275 and tells us a horror story about RAO, Russia’s version on GEMA
  • Nehemiah Dacres wrote to tell us that Yorba, makers of Shotwell are working on a new email client
  • Gary wrote to tell us that openSUSE 12.2 is out and that he’s upgraded from 12.1 without a problem

Song: Sally Anne by The Acousticals (licensed Creative Commons BY-SA 3.0)
item.itunes:subtitle: Fab is back from holiday, Firefox 15 is out, Java is pwned, Fedora 18 is postponed (again), Diaspora is fail and Linux Mint founder Clem calls Nautilus a catastrophe
item.itunes:summary: Fab is back from holiday, Firefox 15 is out, Java is pwned, Fedora 18 is postponed (again), Diaspora is fail and Linux Mint founder Clem calls Nautilus a catastrophe
item.itunes:author: fab@sixgun.org

item.title: Linux Outlaws 275 – Man on the Moon
item.dc:creator: linuxoutlaws@sixgun.org (Sixgun Productions)
item.description: Google warns of using Adobe Reader on Linux, Dropbox tests two-factor authentication, Fedora 18 schedule slips by a week, Fab rants on GEMA,Twitter joins up with Linux Foundation and VMware applies to join OpenStack
item.content:encoded:
Uncut video version of this episode on YouTube

R.I.P. Neil Armstrong

0:02:00 INTRODUCTION

  • Hangouts on air now available in Germany — you can watch our show live from there…
  • The Stephen Fry video from OggCamp 12
  • Fab will be on holiday for a week, so we will be skipping an episode

0:12:36 RELEASES & NEWS

  • Ubuntu 12.04.1 LTS
  • Apache Server 2.4.3
  • VirtualBox 4.1
  • LibreOffice 3.5.6
  • Apache OpenOffice 3.4.1
  • Banshee 2.5.0
  • GIMP 2.8.2
  • FlightGear 2.8.0
  • Warning on critical Java hole
  • Google warns of using Adobe Reader – particularly on Linux
  • Dropbox tests two-factor authentication
  • German court upholds “GEMA Vermutung” (German link)
  • Fedora 18 schedule slips by a week
  • The OggBox
  • Compiz now supports OpenGL ES 2.0; Unity 2D dropped from Ubuntu 12.10 “Quantal Quetzal”
  • Twitter joins up with Linux Foundation
  • Google: Apple vs Samsung does not relate to Android’s core
  • Arch Linux proposes switch to systemd; Systemd to secure system log information against attacks
  • Oracle secrecy threatens open MySQL development
  • The White House open sources its petition platform
  • Calligra plans new professional writing program
  • Multi-channel audio support for Wine
  • VMware applies to join OpenStack

1:17:49 FEEDBACK

Supporters: Michael Lamb, Martin Bastow and Ben Farnfield — from Flattr: renhuh, johanv, Mattias Ohlsson, Bernd Schlapsi and viis

  • Matthias recommends the Claws Mail email client
  • Georg Ottinger tells us about OggStreamer, a standalone device for streaming radio shows
  • Jake Roberts sends us a link to a video of Ben Heck building a BBC Micro-style case for the Raspberry Pi

We had other emails from: Steven Dorries, Gary and Ryan

Song: Sharp Dressed Man by The Beards (all rights reserved)

The End of the World (for Beardless People)
item.itunes:subtitle: Google warns of using Adobe Reader on Linux, Dropbox tests two-factor authentication, Fedora 18 schedule slips by a week, Fab rants on GEMA,Twitter joins up with Linux Foundation and VMware applies to join OpenStack
